ygData.subject: Re: Thesis on characteristics of HyperNEAT, plus a Java implementation of HyperNEAT [1 Attachment]
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Jeff, Thanks for your positive feedback. :) I did consider submitting some of it for publication, but to be honest I didn t want to submit to a conference

Subject: Re: Thesis on characteristics of HyperNEAT, plus a Java implementation of HyperNEAT [1 Attachment]
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=360173778; y=mzoRA1Ka1OqAi3X5pv5IMn4_iO9_j-w3aVr9Eyxw6vJEoP5s53TdTt_-lAgki2Rso3QJQYZYsQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: olivercoleman04

Hi Jeff,

Thanks for your positive feedback. :) I did consider submitting s=
ome of it for publication, but to be honest I didn't want to submit to a co=
nference where I'd have to travel overseas due to climate change considerat=
ions (eg GECCO this year), and haven't gotten around to looking for other o=
pportunities.

I don't specifically remember trying the "discrimination bet=
ween complex non-solid shapes" experiments without incremental scaling, how=
ever I seem to remember per-generation performance being much better when s=
tarting with a higher resolution (but despite this the use of scaling reduc=
ed the total run-time of the experiments). I suppose that at higher resolut=
ions the (representation of the) shapes become increasingly different (up t=
o a point depending on the similarity and complexity of the images, anyway)=
 and so it's easier to evolve a function that can differentiate between the=
m.

I don't know how I forgot the 3D representation experiment you performe=
d; I read that paper (at least once), but I guess some time before I wrote =
my thesis! I just had another look at it, and am wondering what the results=
 would have been like for:
 * differently engineered 3D representations, eg=
 the "The HipIO joint was placed just below the HipFB joint in the Z dimens=
ion", what would have happened if these were more widely separated?, and 
 =
* randomised 3D representations.
Did you perform any other experiments (in =
large or small numbers) using 3D representations? This is an area I'd like =
to explore some more.

Cheers,
Oliver
